David Saff wrote:

>  > I suspect you don't want to get into "JUnit lint" territory
> 
> ... is true, I'm not yet convinced to change this. In short, I could
> make @Ignore @BeforeClass declare the class malformed, with specific
> directions to the developer about how to accomplish what they want.
> Would that meet the actual pain point?

Not bad. You could issue a "doesn't do what you think it'd do" warning 
in this case.

> It's of course not impossible to change JUnit to have well-formed,
> somewhat well-formed, and not-at-all well-formed classes, but I'm not
> yet convinced that there's pain pushing me in that direction.

Instead of thinking of the well-formedness of the test, just think of 
the correct use of the annotation. "@Ignore has no effect here."

>  > but at the
>  > same time, users are quite logically trying to use @Ignore in a context
>  > you didn't intend, but that nevertheless makes sense to them, and in
>  > general.
> 
> Very true, and I hadn't given that enough credit yet.

I feel you: I don't like to deal with that stuff, either, in general. 
Damn users.

>  > If @Ignore-ing a @Test stops the test from running, then why doesn't
>  > @Ignore-ing a @Before stop the before from running? This is, perhaps,
>  > why I wouldn't support @Ignore, but would rather just ask the test
>  > writer to remove the @Test annotation when he doesn't want the test to
>  > run. I don't know that @Ignore provides better results than removing the
>  > @Test annotation temporarily.
> 
> Is this a separate issue? Are you suggesting that, given the choice,
> you would not have included @Ignore, with the attendant reminder to
> un-@Ignore sometime in the future, in JUnit at all? I'm curious about
> that position, but first want to make sure if it is your position.
> Thanks,

I would certainly not have included @Ignore as a decorator annotation of 
@Test. Especially in light of this, I would want to change it to 
@IgnoreTest /replacing/ @Test, as that better reveals the intent behind 
the annotation. As long-time readers here know about me, I favor 
features that reflect the intent of JUnit as a TDD tool, and I don't see 
@Ignore as reflecting that intent. @Ignore is more of a regression 
testing feature.

Take care.
